job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in San Antonio, TX
pros: Flexible hours Great work life balance
cons: There are no cons whatsoever.

review_title: Good place to work as a student
job_title: Student Office Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: * Flexible Hours * Simple tasks - done within the first hour * Understanding employer * You can do homework most of the shift - they value you as a students and recognize you have shifting priorities * Supervisor willing to write letters of recommendations for internships
cons: You can be working with students who are unreliable and they may ask for someone to cover the shift last minute. After hours there is no one checking to see if students are actually doing their job, so sometimes the closer is left to do everything. Unreliable staff continues to be hired back the following semesters.

job_title: Residence Life Coordinator in San Antonio, TX
pros: Some colleagues are great people
cons: Terrible leadership, low pay, performative involvement of staff, no room for growth, workload too large, hierarchical for no reason, pettiness from “leaders”

job_title: Editor-In-Chief in San Antonio, TX
pros: -Flexible student/employee schedule -Make your own hours
cons: -Publications offices/workspace was a crowded basement but the school is trying to renovate

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: great faculty, hands-on learning, very accessible research
cons: I wish we could've had more experience coming up with novel projects

job_title: Student Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Good to work on campus so you don't need to drive around the city to work. Good for getting a schedule that works with your classes.
cons: Student Assistant jobs don't usually pay as much as you may get at a part-time job off campus.

job_title: Student Library Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: There are many books to choose from.
cons: The wage is a con for sure.

job_title: Campus Tour Guide in San Antonio, TX
pros: I enjoyed the opportunity to inspire future trinity tigers
cons: mediocre pay. aggressive hiring process, difficult job to land

job_title: Program Manager in San Antonio, TX
pros: Benefits and Time off. Mission-driven.
cons: HR has arbitrary rules and is unwilling to discuss career opportunities.

job_title: Tour Guide in San Antonio, TX
pros: -Flexible Schedule -Supportive Boss -Fun Tour Opportunities -Supportive Environment -Great Pay
cons: -Sometimes tours can be difficult -Slight ambiguity in scheduling and sometimes there are last-minute tours you get called in to -Requires you to be on call which can be hard if you live far from campus

job_title: Director of Disability Services in San Antonio, TX
pros: I have so enjoyed my experience working for Trinity University. From the very caring and dedicated faculty to the staff that are truly focused on student success, it's rare to find a place like Trinity (a small, private, selective liberal arts institution) in the middle of a Texas city like San Antonio.
cons: While they have been working on pay equity, the university lags behind so many in pay for professionals and support staff.

job_title: Career Counselor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Passionate kind diverse staff and faculty, fun campus events , highly DEI conscious, gorgeous campus, nice offices and buildings, convenient location to highway and restaurants, motivated elite students, great benefits, agile, transparent and caring leadership
cons: High turnover (on trend with national Great Resignation), salaries not high

job_title: Lifeguard in San Antonio, TX
pros: Flexible hours and good pay.
cons: The job could get boring at times but that's good.

review_title: I thought TU AR&D would be awesome...
job_title: Director in San Antonio, TX
pros: Beautiful campus, smart & cordial students; amazing faculty; opportunity for growth, tuition comped for your household
cons: Pride and arrogance,  cross- divisional leadership power struggles, and some individuals in leadership positions should not be in leadership positions

job_title: Phonathon Caller in San Antonio, TX
pros: It's hours worked well for a full time student, it allowed for one to make connections as well as learn how to communicate with individuals, even if it meant asking for a donation.
cons: It was not understanding of inability to work due to school work. It is a student job on campus and obviously school comes first and they were not understanding when school came before work. They didn't seem to care.

job_title: Motor Learning and Behavior in Silver Spring, MD
pros: Awesome Dean Mary Romanello. A honor to meet her and observe her counseling skills. Very good environment to study in the school. Very quiet and computer availability to study. Moodle is very user friendly for students and Professors.I was a male teacher in an all female school( Motor Learning and Behavior and I thank Dean Mary for the great learning experience.
cons: Students were mixed on motivation, some motivated to study some not. Sometimes nervous about greeting fellow Professors because of the somber environment.

review_title: Over the long term, it has been good, but it has diminished over time.
job_title: in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great colleagues, interesting students, supportive staff, excellent retirement benefits and tuition exchange for family members.
cons: Less than optimal compensation with regards to salary and fringe benefits for faculty and staff.

job_title: Residential Computer Consultant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Friendly environment, good pay. Bosses at the ITS are extremely cool individuals and nice people. We usually talk about TV shows because everyone in the office shares the love for breaking bad and Dexter, etc. The work schedule is flexible. You get to work with the smartest students (and sometimes professors) in addition to the staff.
cons: Limited opportunities. Trinity is a college, therefore there are limited chances of promotion and other opportunities within the college.

job_title: Chemistry Stockroom Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: The community is one of the best one can experience. All of the staff are supportive and the faculty are some of the best I have ever directly observed.
cons: The pay is quite terrible compared to some of the other available opportunities. The faculty is quite unaware of the plight surrounding the pay of teaching assistants, even though they are some of the brightest minds one can find within a 250 kilometer radius.

job_title: Financial Services Center Worker in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Very Flexible with Your Class Schedule
Great Opportunity to Learn 
Coworkers Very Friendly
Low Pressure and Stress
Campus is Beautiful
cons:
Minimum Wage Generally
Can Become Tedious at Times
Other than that there are no real cons to the job as far as I have encountered

review_title: Great people, environment and benefits...not great pay or mobility
job_title: Coordinator in San Antonio, TX
pros: The people are amazing to work with as everyone really loves what they do. That helps create an inclusive environment that fosters great innovations. The benefits are nothing to snuff at: great health (though expensive) 401K and other benefits
cons: Do not expect great mobility here unless you plan to stay around 30-40 years and keep pursuing education and certifications for higher positions and pay

job_title: Advertising Director in San Antonio, TX
pros: Work with clients around the San Antonio area. Manage a staff. Set advertising goal and work in fast paced marketing setting.
cons: Very time consuming alongside taking classes, although the practical work experience is a plus - great resume builder. Managing a staff also gives a lot of good experience.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Loved being able to work on my own terms by reaching out to advertising contacts when convenient. My earnings were totally determined by how hard I worked, which was very satisfying. Have referenced this job in nearly every interview I've had (and received offers from each interview).
cons: Had to be very prompt in replying to contacts. Was glued to my phone anyway, so this wasn't a big issue.

review_title: Don't Get Involved With This Institution!
job_title: Associate Professor in San Antonio, TX
pros: It might not be bad if you are white, male, and don't care about salary
cons: It's corrupt and abuses its faculty.  It cares nothing of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, and does nothing to protect women. My experience was a disaster, and the University did nothing to help me after years of sexual harassment. This is just one problem:  others are too numerous to mention here.

review_title: A great institution. A lot of red tape.
job_title: Associate Director in San Antonio, TX
pros: The community at TU is great. Friendly colleagues and excellent students.
cons: There is a lot of red tape between divisions and various posturing and power struggles at various levels. It can be difficult to see progress on job functions when so many offices can hinder your progress.

job_title: Manager in San Antonio, TX
pros: There are great and friendly people. Working to advance the mission of higher education is stimulating.
cons: Change management is especially difficult. Clinging to inefficient and outdated processes is in many cases supported by leadership.

review_title: I get to work with amazing people every day at Trinity.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Beautiful campus, amazing guest lectures all the time (David Cameron this month), free food at least twice a week, stunning downtown views.
cons: None that are worth mentioning. The students and faculty are a pleasure to work with. A true gem in San Antonio.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Collaborative environment, easy to create or initiate change, dedicated colleagues, fantastic students
cons: Overworking/work-life balance is a struggle. Small University means that you wear LOTS of hats and your job is often a variety of jobs.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: On campus, low skill requirement, can get great contacts from Academic departments as well as connect better with professors.
cons: Pay is very low. Depending on your federal work study arrangement, you may only work a limited number of hours.

review_title: Great job at a great school
